title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Subchapter I of chapter 73 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new section on Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary shall organize the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined Networks aligned with the Department's mission and specific healthcare requirements of veterans. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network aligns with the Department's mission and veterans' healthcare needs. Networks must implement national goals and maintain integrated healthcare systems. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network aligns with the Department's mission by implementing alliances with other healthcare organizations and managing regional budgets. The Secretary oversees regional budgets for Veterans Health Administration activities in the Network, ensuring alignment with Department guidelines and balancing budgets annually. National metrics are used to develop systems for delivering highly satisfactory healthcare to patients and their families. The Secretary ensures efficient and safe healthcare delivery rated highly satisfactory by patients and families. High-quality clinical programs are provided in Department medical centers, outpatient clinics, and other healthcare settings within the Network. The Secretary ensures efficient healthcare delivery in Department medical centers and other healthcare settings within the Network, reducing duplicate functions and promoting collaboration among Veteran Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary oversees the administrative, operational processes, and practices of the Veterans Health Administration, promoting collaboration among Veteran Integrated Service Networks for patient care, safety, education, and research. This includes assessing consolidation or realignment of functions with other networks and relevant offices/entities. The Secretary oversees operational support functions in collaboration with other Veterans Integrated Service Networks and offices/entities within the geographical area, including Veterans Benefits Administration, National Cemetery Administration, and Department of Defense offices, installations, and facilities. The Department of Defense oversees offices, installations, and facilities of each branch of the Armed Forces, including reserve components. It also includes Coast Guard offices, State and local agencies assisting veterans, medical schools, government offices, and emergency services at federal, State, and local levels. The Secretary ensures that various organizations, including medical schools, government offices, emergency services, and community organizations, develop and share innovations and best practices within the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary ensures that Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices at local, regional, and national levels, with each network having one headquarters office co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The Secretary determines the location of headquarters offices for Veterans Integrated Service Networks, which are co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers. The Secretary can employ up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors at each headquarters. An annual report on employment at these headquarters must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary determines the location of headquarters offices for Veterans Integrated Service Networks, co-located with VA medical centers, employing up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors. An annual report on employment at these headquarters is submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, detailing the number of individuals employed at each headquarters and within the Veterans Health Administration in each network. The annual report includes details on the number of employees at each Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, their titles, and the impact on the budget. The Veterans Health Administration conducts a triennial review of the structure and operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, assessing the impact on the Department's budget. The Secretary will review and assess the Veterans Integrated Service Networks every three years, submitting a report with recommendations to improve them to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary will review and assess the Veterans Integrated Service Networks every three years, submitting a report with recommendations for improvement to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, including legislative or regulatory actions. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This realignment is to comply with section 7309(a) of the title, with a review every three years for improvement recommendations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the Act's enactment. This includes combining specific networks to streamline operations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the Act's enactment. This includes combining specific networks to streamline operations, such as merging Veterans Integrated Service Network 4 and 5, 9 and 10, and 11 and 12 into single networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 15, 17, 18, and 19 will be combined into single networks as part of the consolidation efforts by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Consolidation efforts by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs involve combining Veterans Integrated Service Networks 17 and 18, 19 and 20, and 21 and 22 into single networks. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including merging Veterans Integrated Service Network 21 and 22 into a single network. Headquarters of the consolidated networks will be retained in the same location as before. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating Veterans Integrated Service Networks, retaining one headquarters in the same location as before. Any other headquarters will be eliminated to meet specific requirements. Reemployment assistance will be provided for individuals whose positions are affected by the headquarters elimination. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide reemployment assistance for individuals affected by the elimination of headquarters, aiming to find new positions within the Department of Veterans Affairs. An implementation plan must be submitted to the Committee of Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks not co-located with VA medical facilities. An implementation plan must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks not co-located with VA medical centers upon lease expiration. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks not co-located with VA medical centers upon lease expiration. If the Secretary renews or enters into a new lease to keep the headquarters in the same location, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs before renewing or engaging in a new lease for underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, detailing the reasons for the renewal or engagement, including a list of medical centers with underutilized buildings and square footage information. The report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs must include details on underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, such as the number of buildings, total square footage, current lease cost, and new lease cost. The report must include details on underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, such as the current lease cost, new lease cost, and square footage to be leased. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Each center will report to the Under Secretary of Health and will have specific functions outlined. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will report to the Under Secretary of Health and assess finance operations, compliance activities, and outreach efforts to veterans. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks in conducting outreach to veterans who served in specific operations, programs for women veterans, addressing homelessness among veterans, and other related programs. The Secretary may hire employees and contractors to carry out functions of regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration. This includes assessing programs for women veterans, addressing homelessness among veterans, and other related activities of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary may hire employees and contractors for regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration, co-located with VA medical centers. The location of each center is determined by the Secretary, with the option to choose a non-co-located site. The Secretary may establish regional support centers co-located with VA medical centers, but can choose a non-co-located site with approval from the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must provide a report explaining the decision to not co-locate a regional support center with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The report should include a list of underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, the total underutilized square footage, and details on any leases entered into by the Secretary. The Secretary must provide a report on the number of Veterans Health Administration buildings and total underutilized square footage in each medical center. Additionally, details on any leases for regional support centers, including cost and square footage, must be included in the report. Initial staffing for regional support centers should also be addressed. The Secretary must report on underutilized square footage in Veterans Health Administration buildings and leases for regional support centers. Initial staffing for regional support centers involves transferring employees from headquarters to cover similar functions. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
